content.body: can anyone speak to the increased rigor Microdata has over Microformats? /cc @foolip
I can describe examples, but don’t know if I can adequately summarise it

things like using itemscope & itemprop vs class, defining href/datetime to be content and not text inside element, more explicit separation from content than uF (itemprop vs abbr and class-title patterns)…
boblet: the main "increased rigour" is the same as the difference between html and xml -- you can parse microdata, like you can parse xml, without knowing the vocabulary in use.
Hixie: ahah. good I checked
and welcome back—how was the ski-ing?
So, HTML5 is moving ahead pretty fast in adoption.
What will happen when everyone starts adopting it when it's supposedly years from being ready.
JonathanNeal: why use future tense? I’ve already done 3 or 4 HTML5 sites
no universe implosion (… at least, so far)
boblet: not bad, not bad
JonathanNeal: many parts are ready now, what do you mean?
Hixie: plenty to do yet
Opp, was having connection issues with IRC.
heh
boblet, yea we're releasing our next version of the portal as HTML5.
And our website is HTML5.
well, there you go.
nothing happened, right?
Well, I was wondering what impact this has on the draft.
Since before I heard it wouldn't be ready for so long, I mean, is it still in a stage where elements can be added and removed?
JonathanNeal: figcaption is the newest element I remember, and that was a month or two ago
definitely change is still possible, and we may have to change stuff
that’s the early adopter price I guess
at the same time your experiences can directly help improve the spec, so that’s a pretty good reward
Yea, I wish I was able to contribute more.
heh. every bit counts
But talking with you here, getting your input and implementing HTML5 in our stuff I suppose means something, a lil somethin.
real world implementation feedback means a lot I think
The guy or girl who puts together HTML5 Doctor does a pretty good job too, generally in my experience.
there’s six authors … at the moment ;-)
they’ve also had at least one guest  author
The most confusing new elements for me to learn about was section and article.
I was so confused about when the context was right for either one, and I wasn't comfortable putting section outside (around) an article.
JonathanNeal: http://oli.jp/2009/html5-structure1/
Well, there wasn't THAT when I started last summer, there was this room.
I wrote that June last year ;-)
Yes, I saw.
but IRC is better than an article, so you found the best place
I've been continually taking in input for our master portal layout in the product (I've been keeping a demo @ http://sandbox.thewikies.com/html5-layout/ )
maybe you should write some articles too
With those optional theme changes at the bottom, it's kind of like our csszen type layout.
Everybody does it
but it's fun to do with html5
So, if I have an article and there's an image associated with the article
with figure / figcaption be appropriate?
10.50 RC out now
you're faster than Google Reader
suspicious o_O
meanwhile I ordered a new hard drive
it does not seem too hard to install it
Well, I am in the office, so it's not so surprising I'm quick ;P
now I need to buy a writable-CD
gsnedders, dah
fortunately the current hard drive is not so broken that everything stops working
When I had HDD throw up loads of SMART warnings, I tried to dd everything off it
It failed. It starting making clunking sounds and dd gave I/O error.
Be careful though
Seagate apparently does some weird things with SMART that normal SMART tools cannot fully read properly
the only potential issue is that the new hard drive is not compatible I suppose
Causing all kinds of false positives (or negatives)
So just because it seems like it currently works doesn't mean it'll keep working
right, I just noticed the corrupt sector count has increased since yesterday
Which brand?
hitachi
I bought a new one with faster RPM and more space
Ah. Not sure of those, but do they have a tool as well that you can download? Like SeaTools for Seagate disks?
why would I need a tool?
That's always a good test to see how badly it is dying, if it is.
annevk: do you keep using the broken hard drive?
annevk: See point about SMART being misleading above. ;)
hsivonen, it's all I have at the moment
annevk: dangerous activity
the palimpsest disc utility tells me to replace it
hsivonen, I see
guess I better make a backup nowish then
Aye, you should. :)
At least now while you still seem to be able to read data from it.
you guys scare me
Welcome to the world of failing HDs
I recommend not shutting down the computer and not using it for anything but sending the files over network to another computer
or over USB to an external hard drive
i hope the new drive arrives soon
drives were in short supply everywhere, will prolly take a few days...
i'll back up stuff, make an iso tomorrow and I guess after that we'll see when it dies
hopefully not before all that...
i prolly have warranty on this hard drive too I guess
oh well, it's only EUR 80 or so
So, if I have an article and there's an image associated with the article would figure and figcaption be appropriate?
JonathanNeal, sure
And <summary> is like the heading of <details>, like - <h1> is to <article> as <summary> is to <details>
wonders in which language "e.g." implies an exhaustive listing
not dead yet
and almost fully backed up
computer did crash once
presumably related to a disk failure
so much fun
instead of booting from a CD, can you boot from an iso file on an external HD assuming your internal HD is empty?
Presumably that depends on your bios
I would guess no
But only based on pessimism
ok, i'll buy some cds
and hopefully my hd survives long enough
i'm not going to do nothing until i get that cd and new hd though, that'd way boring
annevk: http://www.neowin.net/forum/index.php?showtopic=305843&view=findpost&p=585740612 suggests a way to copy the contents of an ISO onto a hard disk and boot it
though presumably you'd want to set up the boot partition on the external disk too
and getting it to boot from that disk instead of from the first one seems likely to be BIOS-dependant
s/ant/ent/
(If you have a USB memory stick then it ought to be possible to boot from that, instead of a CD)
oh i do
that sounds interesting
starts reading https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Installation/FromUSBStick
oh lol, you can even run the entire OS from a CD
euh, USB
Hard to understand how Larry can complain about a lack of "transprency in standards" with a straight face
Context: http://masinter.blogspot.com/2010/02/masinter-and-web-standards-oh-my.html
can't find "trans" on that page
oh euh
nm
Ignore my typo
Apparently I can't spell anymore
hi
bah, creating an bootable usb stick is failing and also very slow
failing?
apparently some checksum is not matching after it wasted about 10 minutes copying some files
also formatting the usb drive fails about half of the time
wonders if it's the usb drive
it seems I finally succeeded
that only took 45min
o_O
now I need my new HD and it should be all good
Is there some official source from Google that says what codecs Chrome supports by default?
Or, rather, at all?
Chromium too.  I think that's "whatever ffmpeg supports, if you compile it right", but I don't have a reliable source.
is editing <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_layout_engines_(HTML5)>, needless to say
afaik it's h.264/theora for chrome and just theora for default chromium
not sure where this is documented
Yes, but what about other stuff like WAV PCM and AAC?  Also, I need an actual source.
Some dude already reverted some of my changes, so I need to actually substantiate them.
AryehGregor: I bet if you ask on #chromium someone can help you
othermaciej, I did, but didn't get a reliable source.  I went with a link to source code, but not sure if the other guy will think that's acceptable . . . it doesn't really meet Wikipedia guidelines.
Of course, the rest of the article is largely unsourced, so big deal.
what could be more reliable than the source code?
are you looking for an official policy statement from Google?
Source code is reliable, but it can't reasonably be interpreted without programming knowledge *and* quite a bit of tinkering.
AryehGregor: I think Chrome also supports MPEG AAC audio, from looking at that source code
You could write a blog post summarising the source, and then link to that
I wouldn't mind if it were a blog post by a Chrome developer, or even a blog comment, just something that has a clear statement and is at least vaguely authoritative.
AryehGregor: (as does Safari)
AryehGregor: there was a post about their plans on the WHATWG list, but it might not have enough detail
Philip`, I'm certainly not reliable as a source here, I don't have any actual knowledge.
Hmm, do you remember when that was or what it was called or whatever?  Or have a link?
this article says Chrome will support H.264 video, AAC audio, and Ogg Theora and Vorbis: http://news.cnet.com/8301-17939_109-10250958-2.html
Thanks.
quoting a Google speaker
it does not cite MP3, but from the source that does appear to be supported as well
Chromium is actually more important to me, because he put "Yes" for H.264/MP3 for WebKit, and I changed it to "Depends" because Chromium doesn't support those by default.
(although in practice it usually will if it's a distro Linux package using system libraries, and non-Linux users are unlikely to use Chromium)
AryehGregor: besides Chromium there are also the Gtk and Qt ports of WebKit which also depend on how the relevant media framework is configured
the Gtk port supports whatever GStreamer supports
AryehGregor: do Linux distros generally package H.264? Fedora 11, at least, did not
Do you have a quotable source for that?  I could give a link to the IRC logs, but that would probably be considered unreliable.  :)
AryehGregor: I don't know if I have a source other than source code, but I can try googling
http://www.linux.org/news/2007/12/17/0001.html

roc, the Ubuntu Chromium package lets you install it either with or without non-free codecs.  I suspect that typically the non-free codecs would be installed, since they're needed to play lots of content users would be likely to have.
I guess this would be the better reference: http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2007/12/html5-video-support-in-gtkwebkit.ars
othermaciej, thanks.  I'll see what the guy says.
AryehGregor: I don't know how that works, since AFAIK Canonical doesn't have a license to distribute H.264
codec

roc, I think it's some dodgy thing where it's not installed by default, and you have to click through some dialog saying you have the right to use the codec -- e.g., live in a country where it's not patented.  (I'm sure it's not patented in, say, Iran.)
I don't know how they get away with it.
Maybe they do have some kind of license for some of the key codecs.  IIRC, Dell licenses them for its Ubuntu computers.

now I get to rant about how MPEG-LA selective enforcement conspires with well-meaning free software advocates promoting "legal workarounds" to hopelessly confuse the situation and reduce the chance we'll get a truly free solution
Chromium is only in PPAs in current versions, and this page makes it seem like the chromium-codecs-ffmpeg* packages aren't yet available in Lucid: http://packages.ubuntu.com/lucid/chromium-browser
So as far as Chromium specifically goes, Canonical might not officially know about what codecs are available.
I do know that I can play patented formats in Totem and so on, and I don't think I ever did anything except maybe click through some dialog very early on.
Fabien Tassin is the Chromium PPA maintainer, you could ask him.  He's on freenode right now with the nick fta.
